fields.headline: Giants' cause weighs heavy
fields.standfirst: Blue Chip firms must do more to survive than hire a new CEO, writes  Robert Heller
fields.trailText: Blue Chip firms must do more to survive than hire a new CEO, writes Robert Heller
fields.body:
How the mighty are falling. Despite this year's collapse in technology stocks, the fast-moving newcomers still boast market capitalisations hugely above those of the old grandees of world business. Cisco Systems, for a spectacular instance, is worth 50 per cent more than General Motors, IBM, Eastman Kodak and Gillette put together.

Objectors might protest that this merely expresses the difference between an other-worldly price-earnings ratio and reality. But the statistic also tells an unflattering truth about the giants. They have lost the effortless supremacy - based on global spread, unlimited wealth, invincible brands and touchingly loyal customers - which they once so richly enjoyed. Instead, they must battle to defend their markets and their margins against pressures, including new competition, over which they have no control. Some resort to mergers and acquisitions in self-defence, which may well double their trouble. Some seek to transform their creaking empires into powerhouses of modern management, at which most fail lamentably.

General Motors is striving to develop e-commerce. But its profits are poor, its market share limp and its European returns pitiful. In the same industry, Daimler-Benz bought Chrysler (and double-trouble) while changing spectacularly from luxury supplier to manufacturer of everything from whacky Smart runabouts to lush lim ousines. Its latest profits are down by 30 per cent. At Kodak, Xerox and Procter & Gamble, chief executive officers have left after proving unable to crack severe marketplace problems. The same fate has just overtaken Peter Salsbury at Marks & Spencer. Why do these once-mighty management machines find it so desperately difficult to extricate themselves from stagnation?

One reason is the depth of the holes that they and/or their predecessors have dug. Kodak's loss of market share to Fuji, and its failure to develop new businesses, turned it from leader to follower; sales fell by a quarter over the Nineties. The hole-diggers customarily ignore the shifting earth beneath their feet - just as the Dome's progenitors brushed aside consultants who doubted the absurd visitor forecasts.

Many a private Dome has been built inside these mega-corporations - such as Kodak's forlorn foray into drugs, or Quaker Oats' 1997 £300 million sale of Snapple (Cadbury Schweppes' latest tipple), three years after a $1.7 billion purchase. Each costly blunder savages a firm's Economic Value Added - the vital difference between capital's cost and its return. Blow $1.4bn for a negative return, and you've created a permanent drag on the finances. When reality creeps (or crashes) in, boards commonly conclude that only a new broom will sweep clean enough. Kodak chose George Fisher for his record at Motorola (now itself troubled). His magic failed. In any event, a new CEO is not enough: replacing the top banana doesn't change a whole overripe bunch.

Senior managers customarily complain about resistance to change among the lowest orders. In fact, resistance among middle managers is both stronger and harder to eradicate. Many are wedded to the post and fearful for their jobs (often with reason). But their conservatism is generally outdone by their seniors. Top executives not only lived under the previous dispensation: they created it. Even Tony Blair, vaguely admitting responsibility for the Dome, is a model of outspoken self-criticism compared with the self-delusion of the typical authors of corporate failure.

The problem with denial is that it delays response - and slow reactions invariably make bad much worse. That is why the over-familiar Supertanker Myth is so dangerous. Corporate captains like to compare their vessels with bulk oil carriers that can only turn at lugubrious speeds. That misses the crucial point. The transformation that they need changes the supertanker into a fleet of smaller, fast-moving (and fast-turning) motor boats. This metaphor was actually used by Heinrich von Pierer, CEO of Siemens, to explain his plans for corporate revolution. Three years on, his flotilla is no more impressive than the supertanker it supposedly replaced, earning half of Hewlett-Packard's profits on 50 per cent more sales. As the Siemens example shows, the groaning of the greats is heard in high technology as well as low, and for the same basic reason. Speedboats and supertankers need wholly different crews.

What can GM shareholders expect from new CEO, Richard Wagoner, who is a 23-year veteran? What can Wagoner expect when he calls on other veteran managers to 'shake off GM's complacent, cautious traditions and take more risks'? You can only sympathise with the analyst who told the Wall Street Journal that, without someone to pressurise slow-moving management, 'there's no such thing as a price earnings ratio too low for a company [GM] with these kinds of characteristics'.

Speed is of the essence. Yet the departed CEO of P&G was berated for trying to force through too much change too fast. His company's 'restructuring' programme, however, is a five-year marathon - excessively long in any era, but an eternity in the Age of the Internet. Twenty years ago, Jack Welch started turning General Electric around with remarkable speed and legendary success, only to conclude that he should have moved faster still. Unless change comes fast and runs swift and deep, mega-companies will go on limping from one stage of underperformance to the next.

The purple passages in between serve only to delude. Restructuring, the euphemism for closures, cutbacks and lay-offs, always pays dividends in the short to medium-term. True transformation, however, will not be achieved unless everybody in all the businesses supports the strategy and its purpose, and is fully and personally involved in its execution - from bottom to top. Note the inversion. At the top, those who have the power are powerless to create change, except by genuinely devolving and sharing that power. Mostly they won't. And that's the great (and the greats') problem.

Robert Heller's latest book, 'Riding the Revolution', written with Paul Spenley, is published by Harper Collins.

webTitle: How to dress down and not look silly

fields.headline: How to dress down and not look silly
fields.trailText: 1 Recognise that Britons are, by tradition, far better at dressing up than dressing down. Few other nationalities can rival the British military uniform, for example. 'We don't do "smart casual" very well,' says Suzi Carberry of image consultant Public i. 'We have more of a classic culture. While British men often look very good in uniform or in a suit, when you see them pushing the trolley in Tesco they often look like an unmade bed.' Look to the Continental Europeans for stylish examples of dressing down.
fields.body:
1 Recognise that Britons are, by tradition, far better at dressing up than dressing down. Few other nationalities can rival the British military uniform, for example. 'We don't do "smart casual" very well,' says Suzi Carberry of image consultant Public i. 'We have more of a classic culture. While British men often look very good in uniform or in a suit, when you see them pushing the trolley in Tesco they often look like an unmade bed.' Look to the Continental Europeans for stylish examples of dressing down.

2 Expect to develop an entirely separate wardrobe if you are dressing down. Trying to wear a suit in a casual fashion is the wrong approach. Just as a soldier would look like a slob if he undid his tunic buttons, so you will look rather lopsided if you wear the suit and throw away the tie, or put on trainers under the pinstripes.

3 Maintain some formal structure in your outfit, and let the casual note come through different colours, patterns and textures. If you start to look scruffy - wearing a shirt without a tie or rolling up your sleeves, for example - you will lose some of the authority that smarter dress automatically gives you. 'Take a little more care in the cut of your jackets,' says Carberry. 'What you really want to avoid is going all floppy.' Baggy trousers, skirts and shirts will make you look like a blob, rather than a force to be reckoned with.

4 Pay particular attention to your neckline. Polo neck sweaters are a major part of James Bond's smart-casual wardrobe, in recognition of the fact that a strong line at the neck usually looks better than a confusion of flapping collars, bare skin, medallions and loose ties.

5 Perform your experiments with patterns, colours and materials on gradually. If you go for loud statements and sudden changes of style you might scare the horses. 'It can be really bad if you get it wrong,' says Carberry. 'It's almost as if your boss is seeing what you are really like. If you don't pay care and attention to yourself, people often assume that you won't pay care and attention to the job you do - even if that is not true.'

6 Play safe with darker colours and more sober dress if you are in doubt. Men, who tend to wear darker colours themselves, are generally less inclined to take people as seriously if they dress in light colours. The MP Martin Bell's white suit has been a source of discussion for decades: he got away with it only because he was so obviously a serious customer in the first place.

webTitle: Lunch, but not as we know it

fields.headline: Lunch, but not as we know it
fields.standfirst: 'Desk-dining', where you order online and food is delivered straight to your work station, saves time - but is it bad for you?  Caroline Palmer  reports
fields.trailText: Why move from your desk at lunchtime when you have so much work to do? If you are lucky your thoughtful employer may decide to subscribe to a service being tried out in the UK by catering and support services company Sodexho which will allow you to order your lunch online and have it delivered to your desk. Forget the power lunch, or even the humble sandwich at the local café, it is 'desk-dining' which is now all the rage.
fields.body:
Why move from your desk at lunchtime when you have so much work to do? If you are lucky your thoughtful employer may decide to subscribe to a service being tried out in the UK by catering and support services company Sodexho which will allow you to order your lunch online and have it delivered to your desk. Forget the power lunch, or even the humble sandwich at the local café, it is 'desk-dining' which is now all the rage.

A new report from Data Monitor, 'Changing Lunch Occasions', has discovered that lunchers are a dying breed throughout much of the UK and the US. 'Time pressures and work demands have resulted in fewer workers taking time out for lunch in recent years. For workers who do not have the time to take a full lunch hour, eating at the desk is becoming increasingly widespread. "Desk-dining" allows the busy worker the option of continuing to work while refuelling for the afternoon ahead. Similarly, workers on the move - perhaps between meetings, offices or clients - are more likely to "grab and go" rather than stop for lunch in a restaurant or motorway service station,' says the report.

Indeed desk-dining is something that social work team leader Sandra Shaw can only dream of at times. 'If I'm on the road I will eat a sandwich in my car in between visiting clients. I never feel that food is worth stopping for. I will sometimes go out at lunchtime for a walk or to do some shopping. But if I am in my office, I'm working.'

It is not for nothing that Data Monitor says that the Spanish lunch like kings and the British like paupers. Incredibly, despite the fact that British workers are entitled to an hour for lunch, the average time taken is just 36 minutes. Yet according to the recent Eurest Lunchtime Report 2000, this is longer than it has been for a decade. While the British and the Americans are eating quickly and eating convenience foods, such as sandwiches, wraps, crisps and chocolate, the Spanish are sitting down with their families for two hours in the afternoon for a three-course meal. This will typically be a salad or vegetable starter, fish or meat course with chips, finished off with fruit or yoghurt.

There are important health implications for this difference in culture which run counter to government initiatives to to try to reduce the levels of disease over the next decade. In Scotland, for instance, where death rates from cancer, heart disease and strokes are higher than in almost every other western industrialised country, the Health Education Board for Scotland is involved in a number of initiatives, including the Health at Work award scheme, to try to reverse the trend. While a lot of emphasis is put on providing healthy food in staff canteens or from vending machines, there is little evidence that employers are being pressed to insist that workers take their full hour for lunch.

Also, the fact that the Eurest report found that sandwiches are still the nation's favourite lunchtime food (chosen by 49 per cent) is cause for concern, according to many nutritionists. Despite the fact that slightly more people (35 per cent) choose sandwiches made with brown/granary bread, compared with 32 per cent opting for sandwiches made with plain white bread, nutritionists, such as Savita Bhandari, say we have far too much wheat in our diets, which can cause a wide variety of health problems.

'We often have wheat for every meal,' says Bhandari. 'A wheat-based cereal for breakfast, a biscuit with our tea mid-morning, a sandwich for lunch, a slice of cake in the afternoon and pasta for supper, is not uncommon.' Bhandari believes that persisting with this kind of diet can trigger a wheat allergy which can be recognised by a variety of symptoms, from tiredness, particularly in the afternoon, stomach cramps, wind, sinus problems and an itchy throat.

'There is nothing wrong with having a sandwich for lunch as long as you eat a variety of different foods at other meals, says Bhandari. 'Porridge for breakfast, for instance, and in the evening rice-based meals or other grains such as pearl barley or buckwheat.'

For hypnotherapist John Bennett, the rushed lunchtime habits of the British are compounded by the fact that so many do not give themselves time to have a proper breakfast either. 'What I see as a therapist working in Canterbury is a lot of people suffering the effects of stress. It is very important to get an overall picture of their lifestyle and one question I always ask is whether they eat breakfast. A very common response is "no". Diet and exercise are essential for physical health and having breakfast is a good investment in your long-term wellbeing. If your body goes for too long without food on a regular basis then this will eventually set up physical and psychological problems.'

According to Data Monitor, the Germans and the Swedes have a particularly balanced approach to working and eating. 'Regarding lunch as the most important meal of the day, the Germans and the Swedes take this opportunity to eat a full hot meal in order to prepare themselves for the rest of the day's work. The thinking is far more in line with medical advice than the behaviour of workers in the US or UK. Consequently, meals are filling and time out is taken in order to have a proper lunch break.'

Meanwhile, innovations continue apace to make it easier to keep on working at your desk during lunch. To go alongside the online ordering, Coca-Cola and Nestlé have just launched a new canned coffee from 40 vending machines in Berlin. While the Germans may be able to maintain a balanced view towards eating, one can't help wondering whether, when it finally arrives in the UK, it won't simply save hard-pressed office workers wasting precious moments waiting for the kettle to boil.

webTitle: Labour's vital mission to carry on reforming

fields.headline: Labour's vital mission to carry on reforming
fields.standfirst: Labour is embarked on its road to the manifesto - and so is the Guardian. In a unique experiment in             British journalism, Guardian specialists draw a sketch of what should form Labour's programme for a             second term. Readers add their thoughts, and the material is given a 'reality check' by former mandarin             Sir Peter Kemp. His critiques appear on our website. Today we look at the constitution
fields.trailText: When the historians come to judge Labour's first term in office, they may well regard constitutional             reform as its most radical achievement. A government condemned for control freakery in its handling of             internal party management has in fact given away more power than any administration since Clement             Attlee presided over the dismantling of the British empire.
fields.body:
When the historians come to judge Labour's first term in office, they may well regard constitutional reform as its most radical achievement. A government condemned for control freakery in its handling of internal party management has in fact given away more power than any administration since Clement Attlee presided over the dismantling of the British empire.

Whether by creating a parliament in Scotland, assemblies in Wales and Northern Ireland or a mayoralty in London, Labour has remade the landscape of the British constitution . This is no abstract achievement, of interest only to political scientists and anoraks. For the way a nation governs itself affects how it is governed: by changing our constitution , we hope not only to get a neater looking system but also better railways, schools or hospitals.

Constitutions matter, and Labour's task for the second term is to sort out the confusion and outright messes left by the overhauls of the first - and then to reform some more. Devolution has certainly left a patchwork of confusion, duplication and redundancy. A second-term clean-up should seek to shift to Edinburgh those extra powers the Scots want and to give Wales (and, in time, Northern Ireland) much the same degree of autonomy - with the eventual aim of confining Westmin ster's workload to those decisions which affect the entire United Kingdom.

Decision-making for England should, where possible, move away from Westminster and towards either local or regional government: that way, power would shift dramatically closer to where people ac tually live. Perhaps an even clearer case of unfinished business than devolution is the House of Lords. Labour's partial reform of the second chamber, by removing all but 92 of the hereditary peers, was a welcome first step - but it has created a new set of problems. The Lords continues to hold up the government's programme, except now Labour cannot dismiss it as an entirely fraudulent body, overwhelmingly selected by aristocratic bloodline.

It has acquired a spurious legitimacy, even though it is barely more democratic than the blue-blood house it re placed. The government should move swiftly in the second term to put aside the timidly conservative proposals of the Wakeham commission and opt for a fully elected second chamber. It could be a much smaller body than the Commons, with members representing regions rather than constituencies - elected at different times from the lower house to ensure a different political complexion. That way it could do the job so sorely lacking in our current system of "fused" rather than separated powers: it could act as a genuine democratic check and balance, holding the executive to account.

Its committees might scrutinise new bills and monitor the progress of ones that have recently been passed, to see if they work in practice. They might also interview and then ratify key public appointments, from cabinet ministers to senior judges.

Chosen separately from the House of Commons, these committees would be wholly independent, entirely out of reach of government whips and unswayed by patronage from Downing Street. At last, we would have a legislature distinct from the executive, a feature of almost every advanced democracy but our own.

Labour should extend the separation of powers in another, much less discussed direction: by peeling the judiciary away from the executive. At present, judges are appointed by an unelected member of the cabinet, the lord chancellor. Instead, Labour should honour its earlier commitment to an independent judicial appointments commission: that body could nominate new judges, who would then be ratified (or not) by the justice committee of a reformed second chamber.

Nor can the Commons leave itself out of this process of change. So long as the executive is drawn from the majority party in the Commons, it is naive to expect the lower house to behave independently: the government, by definition, will always get its way in the end. More realistic is to seek reforms to the way the house works.

In 1997 Labour promised a referendum on a new voting system for the Commons: it should honour that promise in the next term. It should also make good on all its rhetoric of modernisation by dragging Westminster's working procedures out of the Victorian dark ages. Labour should say yes to normal daytime office hours, yes to electronic voting - and yes even to breastfeeding in the chamber.

One last piece of the constitution is left - and it is over-ripe for change. It is unrealistic to imagine any government altering the way we choose our head of state in a single term of office.

But Labour can at least give a formal seal to the process of debate - a debate which is already under way in the country. fields.bodyText: When the historians come to judge Labour's first term in office, they may well regard constitutional reform as its most radical achievement. A government condemned for control freakery in its handling of internal party management has in fact given away more power than any administration since Clement Attlee presided over the dismantling of the British empire. Whether by creating a parliament in Scotland, assemblies in Wales and Northern Ireland or a mayoralty in London, Labour has remade the landscape of the British constitution . This is no abstract achievement, of interest only to political scientists and anoraks. For the way a nation governs itself affects how it is governed: by changing our constitution , we hope not only to get a neater looking system but also better railways, schools or hospitals. Constitutions matter, and Labour's task for the second term is to sort out the confusion and outright messes left by the overhauls of the first - and then to reform some more. Devolution has certainly left a patchwork of confusion, duplication and redundancy. A second-term clean-up should seek to shift to Edinburgh those extra powers the Scots want and to give Wales (and, in time, Northern Ireland) much the same degree of autonomy - with the eventual aim of confining Westmin ster's workload to those decisions which affect the entire United Kingdom. Decision-making for England should, where possible, move away from Westminster and towards either local or regional government: that way, power would shift dramatically closer to where people ac tually live. Perhaps an even clearer case of unfinished business than devolution is the House of Lords. Labour's partial reform of the second chamber, by removing all but 92 of the hereditary peers, was a welcome first step - but it has created a new set of problems. The Lords continues to hold up the government's programme, except now Labour cannot dismiss it as an entirely fraudulent body, overwhelmingly selected by aristocratic bloodline. It has acquired a spurious legitimacy, even though it is barely more democratic than the blue-blood house it re placed. The government should move swiftly in the second term to put aside the timidly conservative proposals of the Wakeham commission and opt for a fully elected second chamber. It could be a much smaller body than the Commons, with members representing regions rather than constituencies - elected at different times from the lower house to ensure a different political complexion. That way it could do the job so sorely lacking in our current system of "fused" rather than separated powers: it could act as a genuine democratic check and balance, holding the executive to account. Its committees might scrutinise new bills and monitor the progress of ones that have recently been passed, to see if they work in practice. They might also interview and then ratify key public appointments, from cabinet ministers to senior judges. Chosen separately from the House of Commons, these committees would be wholly independent, entirely out of reach of government whips and unswayed by patronage from Downing Street. At last, we would have a legislature distinct from the executive, a feature of almost every advanced democracy but our own. Labour should extend the separation of powers in another, much less discussed direction: by peeling the judiciary away from the executive. At present, judges are appointed by an unelected member of the cabinet, the lord chancellor. Instead, Labour should honour its earlier commitment to an independent judicial appointments commission: that body could nominate new judges, who would then be ratified (or not) by the justice committee of a reformed second chamber. Nor can the Commons leave itself out of this process of change. So long as the executive is drawn from the majority party in the Commons, it is naive to expect the lower house to behave independently: the government, by definition, will always get its way in the end. More realistic is to seek reforms to the way the house works. In 1997 Labour promised a referendum on a new voting system for the Commons: it should honour that promise in the next term. It should also make good on all its rhetoric of modernisation by dragging Westminster's working procedures out of the Victorian dark ages. webTitle: FA to hunt high and low for new coach

fields.headline: FA to hunt high and low for new coach
fields.trailText: The FA will look to find the "right person for the job" in replacing Kevin Keegan as England coach, which means they could appoint a foreigner to the role for the first time.
fields.body:
The FA will look to find the "right person for the job" in replacing Kevin Keegan as England coach, which means they could appoint a foreigner to the role for the first time.

Football Association chief executive Adam Crozier made his intentions clear after this evening, following Keegan's resignation in the aftermath of a 1-0 defeat by Germany.

"The only important thing is that we get the right person for the job and if that is a foreign manager then that's who it will be," he said.

"We will not set out to go English or go foreign. The important thing is that England have the best possible manager to take the team forward, not their nationality."

Crozier's comments are somewhat understandable given the paucity of home-grown candidates for the job. The most talented, and tactically astute, English coach remains Terry Venables, but his relations with the FA are still frosty.

Interviewed on ITV this evening, Venables said: "When they appointed [Kevin Keegan] the FA said they didn't want to go back, and by 'going back' they meant me."

Names like John Gregory, Peter Reid and Bryan Robson will undoubtedly be put forward, but none of them have achieved anything of note at club level.

The FA may find it equally difficult to persuade a foreign coach to take on the "impossible job". The most successful managers in the English game, Sir Alex Ferguson and Arsene Wenger, would be unlikely to leave their club jobs and Ferguson, a Glaswegian, has said he would only fill the post if he "could get England relegated."

webTitle: I lost my heart in... the Italian islands

fields.headline: I lost my heart in... the Italian islands
fields.standfirst: Jackie Collins
fields.trailText: Jackie Collins
fields.body:
Why: It is the most relaxing holiday I can think of, and very romantic. About five years ago, some friends invited me on holiday on their yacht, and I absolutely loved it. I have been for the past three years in a row. It is wonderful going into a port and seeing it from the viewpoint of the sea, completely different. I spend about 10 days cruising along the Italian coast, dropping in and out of ports, from island to island. It's the perfect amount of time off for me.

Italy is just such a wonderful setting, although I've not been sailing in other places. I love Italy, the pasta, and the weather which is more seasonal than at home in Beverly Hills. You get occasional rainy days which make you appreciate the sun much more. Usually there are about eight of us onboard so it's rather like a country house party at sea.

The boat is pretty luxurious: it has a bath, a bar, several decks . There isn't a pool so we dive off the boat when we want to go swimming. I sit on the deck under the shade with a great pair of sunglasses, a pair of jeans and a shirt. I'll have my Walkman and several books to catch up with the reading I never have time to do when I am working. And I'll keep my writing pad and pen with me, keeping an eye out for descriptions I can use.

A perfect day: When we are in port I get up and go for a jog and then have lunch al fresco. Get back to the boat, have a sleep, read and then find another restaurant for dinner.

What's the best thing? The pasta. I think it tastes better in Italy than anywhere else in the world.

My advice: Take everything you need with you. You don't want to be running off in every port to buy stuff. Take books to read. On a boat you are away from television, the internet and other distractions, so you can really relax with a book.

 Lethal Seduction by Jackie Collins is published by Simon & Schuster at £16.99.

fields.headline: Unforgettable yew
fields.standfirst: Roly Smith explores Europe's largest yew forest, tucked away almost forgotten in a fold of the South Downs near Chichester
fields.trailText: Roly Smith explores Europe's largest yew forest, tucked away almost forgotten in a fold of the South Downs near Chichester
fields.body:
The mistle thrush busily gorging itself on yew berries in Kingley Bottom did not appear to be unduly worried that it is perhaps the most poisonous of British trees. At least, the hard nut inside that candy-coated berry (correctly known as an "aril") and the dark, dense foliage is deadly, the main symptom being coldly described by the Ministry of Agriculture as "sudden death". But the thrush had no need to worry because the seed passes straight through its digestive system, maybe to start a new yew tree elsewhere.

What the poet Geoffrey Grigson called Kingley Bottom's "black tufted density" is said to be the largest and finest yew forest in Europe, but despite its importance, it is quite difficult to find.

Kingley Vale, as English Nature prefers to call it, was one of the first National Nature Reserves to be established in Britain, in 1952, so in a couple of years it will be celebrating its 50th birthday. But the reserve is a mere stripling compared with some of those venerable trees for which it is famous. Many have already celebrated their 500th birthday, and some may be as much as 1,000 years old.

Kingley Vale is tucked away, hardly signposted, in a chalky fold of Stoke Down and Bow Hill, near the village of West Stoke about three miles north west of Chichester. It's worth the effort to find it because the walk through these incredibly ancient trees transports you through an Arthur Rackham landscape of tortured, twisted trunks and dark, cave-like clearings, where you half expect to see fairies or gnomes at every turn.

The yew is a magical tree suspected by some, including Grigson, to be the Scandina vian "world tree" or Yggdrasil, on which the warrior god Odin hanged himself. Another warrior Norse god, Ull, the deity of bows and skiing, is said to have lived in yew dales.

But there's little evidence to support the old folk tale about English yew wood being used for the longbows that proved to be the ultimate deterrent at battles such as Crécy and Agincourt. That's also the usual reason given for the traditional yew tree which stands sentinel in so many English churchyards. In fact, according to the 17th-century botanist Robert Turner, the yew was often planted there because it "attracts and imbibes putrefaction and gross oleaginous vapours" exhaled from the graves.

Anyway, English bowmen preferred their staves to be made from straight-grained yew wood imported by royal decree with barrels of wine from Portugal and Spain. The English yew timber was far to too knotty and brittle.

Yew reputedly has the hardest coniferous timber in the world, as hard as iron and usually longer-lasting. The oldest wooden artefact found in Britain is a spear made of yew found in the clay cliffs of Clacton-on-Sea in Essex. This precious fragment had survived for some 13,000 years.

Our exploration of Kingley Bottom starts from the small car park at the foot of the hill just west of the church at West Stoke. Through a gate, you follow a stony farm track due north towards the impending woodland, with the vale still tantalisingly out of sight. Passing through some mixed woodland, you emerge again into open countryside to reach a crossroads, where an ancient bridleway crosses Stoke Down. The nature reserve is straight ahead.

Heading north on the way-marked nature trail, the best of the oldest yews are on the right-hand side, about 20 really old twisted veterans. Some of these rich, red writhing trunks seem to take on animal forms, while others just astound with their majestic presence and sheer bulk. It's a little like walking through the hushed nave of a natural cathedral.

Nothing much grows beneath the dense shade of these monarchs of the forest, so the walking is easy and the kids will love the hide-and-seek opportunities offered by the entwining boughs.The local legend is that the original grove of yews was planted to commemorate a battle fought in Kingley Vale by the men of Chichester against marauding Vikings in AD 859. The burial mounds at the top of the vale were supposedly where the slain Viking kings were buried, but they are now known to date from the Bronze Age.

As you leave the ancient grove, once thought to be the meeting place of witches and druids, the vast expanse of Kingley Vale opens up. To the right is the "young yew forest", whose spreading branches are thought to be a mere 100 years old. The trees to the left are generally about 140 years old.

A young yew tree needs quite a bit of help to get started, in particular "nurse" trees such as the low-lying juniper shrub, which English Nature is now trying to encourage in the vale. It protects the young trees from grazing, conserves water in drought, and offers shade to the infant yews.

A steepish climb now begins up the chalky escarpment where 50 species of wild flowers, including bee orchids, have been recorded per square metre on these sweet-smelling slopes.

The sad skeletons of dead yews over to the right on the steep, fenced-off section of the down, were killed when, incredibly, Canadian troops were allowed to use them for target practice during the second world war.

As you approach the top of the coombe, the views to the south extend to the elegant spire of Chichester Cathedral and the snaking inlets of Chichester Harbour, with the silvery glint of the English Channel and the coast of the Isle of Wight beyond.

On the brow of the hill is the simple sarsen stone taken from Fyfield Down in Wiltshire which marks the memorial of Sir Arthur Tansley, first chairman of the Nature Conservancy. This was his favourite viewpoint in the whole of Britain.

The way now swings past two of the burial mounds, also known as the Devil's Humps then left and downhill, through more infant yews and the so-called "birdless grove" to return to the field museum and the short walk back to West Stoke.

The practicals

Kingley Vale is just west of West Stoke, on the minor road between Funtington and Mid Lavant, about three miles north west of Chichester. The walk is about 5 miles with easy woodland walking, followed by a stiffish climb to the top of the coombe. You should allow at least three hours. The best map is Ordnance Survey 1:50,000 Landranger Sheet 197: Chichester and the South Downs. There are pubs in West Lavant (A286 north of Chichester) and Funtington (on the B2146), and the White Horse Inn at Chilgrove on the B2141 is good for dinner. The White Horse Inn, Chilgrove (tel: 01243 535219) is an excellent B&B. Chichester Tourist Information Centre, South Street, Chichester (01243 775888).

On the brow of the hill is the simple sarsen stone taken from Fyfield Down in Wiltshire which marks the memorial of Sir Arthur Tansley, first chairman of the Nature Conservancy. This was his favourite viewpoint in the whole of Britain. The way now swings past two of the burial mounds, also known as the Devil's Humps then left and downhill, through more infant yews and the so-called "birdless grove" to return to the field museum and the short walk back to West Stoke. The practicals Kingley Vale is just west of West Stoke, on the minor road between Funtington and Mid Lavant, about three miles north west of Chichester. The walk is about 5 miles with easy woodland walking, followed by a stiffish climb to the top of the coombe. You should allow at least three hours. The best map is Ordnance Survey 1:50,000 Landranger Sheet 197: Chichester and the South Downs. There are pubs in West Lavant (A286 north of Chichester) and Funtington (on the B2146), and the White Horse Inn at Chilgrove on the B2141 is good for dinner. The White Horse Inn, Chilgrove (tel: 01243 535219) is an excellent B&B. Chichester Tourist Information Centre, South Street, Chichester (01243 775888).

webTitle: The Delicious History of The Holiday

fields.headline: Book of the week
fields.standfirst: The Delicious History of The Holiday, by Fred Inglis
fields.trailText: The Delicious History of The Holiday, by Fred Inglis
fields.body:
Routledge £16.99

There is no doubt that holidays lie near the heart of our emotional life, enjoyed for a fortnight, sustained in the imagination for 11 months of the year. Which is why, when you have a bad one, it is so disappointing. There is no going back.

As the nights draw in and memories begin to fade, here is a book that attempts to explain it all. It is an enjoyable - and scholarly - read, tracing the history of the hols from the Grand Tour, through Thomas Cook's first ventures with temperance tours, the industrialisation of mobility leading to mass tourism, and the coming of the hippie trail to Kathmandu.

And so now there are half a billion of us around the world taking a holiday abroad each year and Fred Inglis, professor of cultural studies at Sheffield University, points out that for the first time "this vast movement of people is impelled neither by terror nor greed, not by starvation nor imperial longings . . . they have come, casually and always temporarily, for fun, from curiosity, for a rest . . . they have come peaceably and in search of that catchall, pleasure; even, it may be, fulfilment."

The book is full of insights. Inglis is able to articulate thoughts that in the rest of most of us do not quite get there. Here is his description of the "Big Apple": "A holiday in New York is formally the same as anywhere else, especially in the simplified machinery of modern tourism: see the selected sight; walk the famous streets; eat the local food; revere the house art; purchase the local speciality. Keep moving, keep spending. But the city will have its way with you, like all great cities; and you will find your own way through it, for as long as you can shake off your blessed guides and their schedules. That is why we all keep going back, why the cities hold up and out their ineffable promise. Modernity has not yet done for wonder."

Europe

Britain: Spend Christmas week in a gamekeeper's cottage in West Somerset for only £316. The four-bedroom cottage, set in the Brendon Hills, sleeps seven and can be booked through Helpful Holidays (01647 433593).

Australasia

Australia: Austravel (0870 055 0206 www.austravel.com) is offering return flights from £499 with Malaysia Airlines, offer valid between January 1 and June 30 2001.

webTitle: The best seafood in Britain and Ireland

fields.headline: Fruits of the sea
fields.standfirst: Rick Stein went on a coastal journey to gather the inspiration and recipes for his new book. He also visited fish restaurants galore. Here is his guide to the best seafood in Britain and Ireland
fields.trailText: Rick Stein went on a coastal journey to gather the inspiration and recipes for his new book. He also visited fish restaurants galore. Here is his guide to the best seafood in Britain and Ireland
fields.body:
I set out on a series of journeys last year to travel right around the coastlines of Britain and Ireland in search of the best seafood, best fish restaurants, fish-and-chip shops, fishmongers, oyster farms, smokers and seafood suppliers on the coast, or at least near enough to the coast to hear the sound of the seagulls.

A book about fishing called The Last of the Hunter Gatherers by Michael Wiggan had partly inspired me to go. The first lines of the book particularly got me thinking.

"There is something about its sea fishermen which defines a nation. Those who ply the waves for a living in all weathers, for whom the horizon is a straight silvery line tipping off the curvature of the earth, whose business is beneath in a dark, pressurised habitat where man has no place, bring back with them on to land a whiff of something far away and intangible."

It bought home to me why the coasts of Britain and Ireland are so special. It is the presence of all those fishing communities and the evidence of fishing, whether it be the sight of brightly painted trawlers from all over Europe tied up in some haven, such as Lochinver in north -west Scotland, safe from the foul weather, or a beam trawler passing inside the little island just off the harbour walls of Mousehole and heading off in a light swell and a scented sharp April breeze past Lamorna Cove towards Lands End and the wide Atlantic.

These images make the magic, which so many of us seek by the sea on our holidays. Seafood restaurants on the coast have always seemed to me to be essential to that allure.

The south west has perhaps a greater variety of species of fish than anywhere else due to its position jutting out into the Atlantic towards the Bay of Biscay, enjoying the benefits of the warm Gulf Stream and plankton-rich water. There's an almost Mediterranean ring to many of the varieties of fish landed - red mullet, john dory, red bream, black bream, trigger fish, grey mullet and even rarities such as scorpion fish, which is used in the Mediterranean for fish soup and bouillabaisse.

Like everywhere else, the best fish comes from small day boats which go out fishing for one day, return in the evening and sell their catch on the market the next morning. Thesouth west is blessed with a number of small fish markets such as Looe, Brixham, Newlyn and Plymouth. Fish especially worth seeking out are turbot, sea bass and Dover sole. The lemon sole of the south coast in early spring is, I think, one of the best fish in the world.

Like everywhere in Britain and Ireland, too, the restaurants that specialise in good local seafood and do it well are few but there number is increasing. The most promising sign of this sea change is the appearance of beach café's such as Porthminster in St Ives, which herald a much more relaxed and informal way of enjoying some good fish by the sea.

Restaurants

I had a charmingly unpretentious dinner at The Bistro on the Beach at Southbourne in Bournemouth one evening last winter, hoping for some big waves at high tide to crash against the toughened-glass windows - it's that close. Much further east in Whitstable, the Whitstable Oyster Company sells oysters, lobster, crab and other shellfish and simple grilled sole, plus a great dish of roasted sea bass with garlic in an old oyster packing house right on the shingle beach.

The South Coast is not teeming with fish any more; there are no fleets of trawlers left. Small local boats land their fish daily and often sell it at the back of the beach, a scenario repeated all the way from West Bay to Whitstable. You can go down on the beach in Brighton, Hastings or Hythe and buy lemon and Dover sole, codling, whiting, monk, flounders, dabs and plaice still jumping.

I'd always considered plaice to be an also-ran fish, great when very fresh but not really worth considering otherwise. That was until the time I went to Portland Bill and met Paul Saunders of Saunders and Wilson. He gave me a couple of plaice to take home of such quality and flavour that I would have sworn I was eating brill. It was firm, sweet and not a bit muddy tasting.

I found a great fishmonger in Southend, certainly not a place where I would have expected to find one, who specialises in skate knobs, a little nugget of meat from the head which makes for extremely agreeable eating.

I couldn't find that many good places to eat in Essex though the Company Shed in West Mersea restored my faith. Modelled on one of those seafood shacks you find all over Maine, it has a similarly ad hoc appeal with oilcloth tables, concrete floors, freshly-boiled lobsters and oysters from just down the road shucked and washed down with a bottle of Chablis that you buy from the off licence just across the road.

Up in Suffolk and Norfolk though, there was much to enthuse about: the Lighthouse at Aldeburgh, the Crown at Snape (seagulls blown a bit inland here) and the Hoste Arms and Burnham Market in Norfolk, where I had some nice grilled cod on the night before a shrimp trawling trip out of Kings Lynn, a memory of a vast seawater boiler on the back of the trawler with steam billowing into a pink sunrise over the Wash, the colour in the sky matching the delicate hue of the good catch of pink shrimps.

Further north was not so well endowed with good restaurants. It's got some of the best fish-and-chip shops, particularly in Whitby and Scarborough, but there seems to be a lack of initiative in celebrating the still rich produce from the North Sea with a restaurant serving bowls of mussels and fish soup, shrimps with mayonnaise, grilled flat fish and roasted halibut or cod.

A honourable exception to this would be Brasserie 21 in Sunderland; down on the docks, a bowl of fish soup with a hot and aromatic rouille was almost better than I make myself.

I expected the east coast would be rather dull compared with the west side, which I knew, but it was delightful, mainly because of the nostalgic evidence of so much fishing activity, most of which has ceased. Communities such as Auchmithie, Sandend, and even Wick once thrived on herring fishing. But it led me to ruminate on the likely fate for most of our coasts - with the decline of fishing many of the coastal communities are destined to become charming but lifeless exhibits of past endeavour.

I found great fish there, though - the still-bountiful produce of the North Sea and North Atlantic. The fish auctions at Peterhead, Fraserburgh, Scrabster and Kinlochbervie are bustling and successful, with good landings of fish from the north all the way to Norway.

At the market in Peterhead, there were a dozen halibut all over 20kg. I was surrounded by boxes of the freshest brown cod I'd ever seen, speckled with yellow and tinged with green, lustrous black; monkfish with heads on for the continental market, lots of coley, or saithe as it is also known, with charcoal backs and unusual species such as wolffish, known locally as rock turbot. I found some pretty memorable meals up there, too - a crab salad at the Cellar at Anstruther on the Fife coast was all that I could have wished for. The Tollbooth at Stonehaven just outside Aberdeen had a wonderful bouillabaisse-style fish stew with really positive flavours.

Restaurants

The Cellar, 24 East Green, Anstruther, Fife, tel: 01333 310378.

The Creel Restaurant with Rooms, Front Road, St Margaret's Hope, Orkney, tel: 01856 831311.

Fish and chips

The Bervie Chipper, Cowgate, King Street, Inverbervie, Aberdeenshire, tel: 01561 361310.

Zanres, 35 Queen Street, Peterhead, Aberdeenshire, tel: 01779 477128.

Peppo's, 51 Ladybridge Street, Arbroath, Angus, tel: 01241 872373.

The Anstruther Fish Bar, The Shore, Anstruther, Fife, tel: 01333 310518.

Early summer this year saw me at the estuary of the river at Glencaple near Dumfries, on the River Nith, taking part in a day of half-net fishing for salmon: you wade up to your chest with a football goal-shaped net held against the flow tidewater to catch fish swimming up river.

Later, we journeyed all the way up the west coast to Cape Wrath, stopping off at Loch Fyne Oysters for smoked salmon, a perfectly-grilled piece of halibut, and, of course, the lovely oysters. Then it was on to the Airds Hotel at Port Appin for a dish of red mullet and langoustine tails with diced red peppers, olive oil and capers. This was followed by a a week of uncharacteristically balmy weather in the far north where I came to the conclusion that the Western Isles presents one of the world's most beautiful vistas.

I went across to Skye, to the Three Chimneys and marvelled at the remoteness of such a place and yet the sophistication of the cooking. The owners, Shirley and Eddie Spear, had left the south east of England for a better life on the Celtic fringe of the country.

I found other restaurants on that coast such as The Summer Islands Hotel at Achiltibuie and the Albannach Hotel at Lochinver with similar idealistic southerners running great fish restaurants. Maybe that escape to a simpler life underpinned my decision to open a restaurant in Cornwall. How wrong I was!

Restaurants

Loch Fyne Oyster Bar and Smokehouse, Clachan Farm, Cairndow, Argyll and Bute, tel: 01499 600236.

Airds Hotel, Port Appin, Argyll and Bute, tel: 01631 730236.

MacCallum's Oyster Bar, The Harbour, Troon, South Ayrshire, tel: 01292 319339.

Nairns, 13 Woodside Crescent, Glasgow, tel: 0141 3530707.

The Three Chimneys, Colbost, Dunvegan, Isle of Skye, tel: 01470 511258.

The Albannach, Baddidarrach, Lochinver, Highlands, tel: 01571 844407.

Pubs

Fish and chips

The Unique Restaurant, 223 Allison Street, Glasgow, tel: 0141 4233366.

Seafresh Foods, West Shore Street, Ullapool, Highlands, tel: 01854 612141.

Go out to West Cork where there's a cluster of Breton restaurants opened by people who saw in that charmed part of the country a pureness and innocence gone from Brittany. Chez Youen in Baltimore is the best of those - great fish and scallops from Bantry Bay and a café too with some good chowders and seafood pizzas. I spent some time searching the west coast of Ireland for good chowders - an interesting culinary migration from France to New England and back to Ireland. I was impressed with the bowl served at Monks pub in Ballyvaughan in County Clare.

Idealism and a wish for a simpler life flourishes in the far west in Connemara, too, where Peter Mantle left a job as a financial journalist in London to set up Delphi Lodge near Leenane. The sea trout fishing here is becoming good again after many lean years caused, Peter thinks, by the fish farms near the lodge whose presence led to an explosion of sea lice which decimated the wild popula tion. The seafood in the evening at the lodge after a day's fishing is pretty special - eaten at an enormous table with Peter and fly fishermen from all over the world and involving a drowsy evening of port and tall fishing stories by a log fire even in summer.

Restaurants

Lawrence Cove House, Bere Island, Beara, Co Cork, tel: 00 353 277 5063.

The Ivory Tower, The Exchange Buildings, 35 Princes Street, Cork, tel: 00 353 2127 4665.

The Yumi Yuki Club, Triskel Arts Centre, Tobin Street, Cork, tel: 00 353 2127 5777.

Kinsale Gourmet Store and Seafood Bar, , Guardwell, Kinsale, Co Cork, tel: 00 353 2177 4453.

Ballymaloe House, Shanagarry, Midleton, Co Cork, tel: 00 353 2165 2531.

Kealy's Seafood Bar, The Harbour, Greencastle, Co Donegal, tel: 00 353 778 1010.

The Narrows Restaurant, 8 Shore Road, Portaferry, Co Down, tel: 028 4272 8148.

Caviston's Seafood Bar, Epicuran Food Hall, Liffey Street, Dublin, tel: 00 353 1878 2289.

Caviston's Restaurant, 59 Glasthule Road, Sandycove, Co Dublin, tel: 00 353 1280 9120.

King Sitric, East Pier, Howth, Co Dublin, tel: 00 353 1832 5235.

Delphi Lodge, Leenane, Connemara, Co Galway, tel: 00 353 954 2211.

The Tannery, Quay Street, Dungarvan, Co Waterford, tel: 00 353 584 5420.

Pubs

Monk's Pub, The Quay, Ballyvaughan, Co Clare, tel: 00 353 6570 77059.

Linnane's Lobster Bar, New Quay, Burren, Co Clare, tel: 00 353 6570 78120.

Dufferin Arms, 35 High Street, Killyleagh, Co Down, tel: 028 4482 1182.

Moran's Oyster Cottage on the Weir, Kilcolgan, Clarinbridge, Co Galway, tel: 00 353 9179 6113.

Mary Ann's Bar and Restaurant, Town Square, Castle townshend, West Cork, tel: 00 353 283 6146.

Fish and chips

Leo Burdock's, 2 Werburgh Street, Dublin, tel: 00 353 1454 0306.

Beshoff Brothers, Harbour Road, Howth, Co Dublin, tel: 00 353 1832 1754.

Finally, I made four journeys to Wales and the North West of England. The highlights of those trips were on two flat and windswept stretches of sand and seaweed, one on the Gower peninsular and the other about seven miles out on Morecambe sands.

In Wales I watched the gathering of cockles and enjoyed the lean fitness of the 60-year-old couple, Maureen and Elwyn Murley, who spend hours every day raking for the shells. It was the sort of stark uncomfortable job, out all year in all weathers, which you would imagine would be no fun, but I've never met two more contented and humorous people; similarly the fluke or flounder gatherers from static nets strung out over the horizon out of Morecambe, who work in a group and rib each other in their homely Lancashire accents far out on the sands where they'd rather be.

I ate well in Wales at the Walnut Tree in Abergevenny, such a long way for a seagull and at the Penhelig Arms Hotel in Aberdovey. I have to admit to missing a couple of restaurants with promising looking menus - Plas Bodegroes at Pwlheli and Morgan's Brasserie in Pembroke - but they were closed as all my trips were made, unavoidably, in the winter.

On the coasts of Lancashire and Cumbria, I found no good fish restaurants; good fish and chip shops, yes, and a lone oyster bar in Blackpool called Roberts, lost in all that garish energy.

Restaurants

Fish and chips

The Cottage, 31 Newhouse Road, Marton, Blackpool, tel: 01253 764081.

It is the presence of all those fishing communities and the evidence of fishing, whether it be the sight of brightly painted trawlers from all over Europe tied up in some haven, such as Lochinver in north -west Scotland, safe from the foul weather, or a beam trawler passing inside the little island just off the harbour walls of Mousehole and heading off in a light swell and a scented sharp April breeze past Lamorna Cove towards Lands End and the wide Atlantic. These images make the magic, which so many of us seek by the sea on our holidays. Seafood restaurants on the coast have always seemed to me to be essential to that allure. The south west has perhaps a greater variety of species of fish than anywhere else due to its position jutting out into the Atlantic towards the Bay of Biscay, enjoying the benefits of the warm Gulf Stream and plankton-rich water. There's an almost Mediterranean ring to many of the varieties of fish landed - red mullet, john dory, red bream, black bream, trigger fish, grey mullet and even rarities such as scorpion fish, which is used in the Mediterranean for fish soup and bouillabaisse. Like everywhere else, the best fish comes from small day boats which go out fishing for one day, return in the evening and sell their catch on the market the next morning. Thesouth west is blessed with a number of small fish markets such as Looe, Brixham, Newlyn and Plymouth. Fish especially worth seeking out are turbot, sea bass and Dover sole. The lemon sole of the south coast in early spring is, I think, one of the best fish in the world. Like everywhere in Britain and Ireland, too, the restaurants that specialise in good local seafood and do it well are few but there number is increasing. The most promising sign of this sea change is the appearance of beach café's such as Porthminster in St Ives, which herald a much more relaxed and informal way of enjoying some good fish by the sea. I had a charmingly unpretentious dinner at The Bistro on the Beach at Southbourne in Bournemouth one evening last winter, hoping for some big waves at high tide to crash against the toughened-glass windows - it's that close. Much further east in Whitstable, the Whitstable Oyster Company sells oysters, lobster, crab and other shellfish and simple grilled sole, plus a great dish of roasted sea bass with garlic in an old oyster packing house right on the shingle beach. The South Coast is not teeming with fish any more; there are no fleets of trawlers left. Small local boats land their fish daily and often sell it at the back of the beach, a scenario repeated all the way from West Bay to Whitstable. You can go down on the beach in Brighton, Hastings or Hythe and buy lemon and Dover sole, codling, whiting, monk, flounders, dabs and plaice still jumping. I found a great fishmonger in Southend, certainly not a place where I would have expected to find one, who specialises in skate knobs, a little nugget of meat from the head which makes for extremely agreeable eating. I couldn't find that many good places to eat in Essex though the Company Shed in West Mersea restored my faith. Modelled on one of those seafood shacks you find all over Maine, it has a similarly ad hoc appeal with oilcloth tables, concrete floors, freshly-boiled lobsters and oysters from just down the road shucked and washed down with a bottle of Chablis that you buy from the off licence just across the road. I expected the east coast would be rather dull compared with the west side, which I knew, but it was delightful, mainly because of the nostalgic evidence of so much fishing activity, most of which has ceased. I found great fish there, though - the still-bountiful produce of the North Sea and North Atlantic. The fish auctions at Peterhead, Fraserburgh, Scrabster and Kinlochbervie are bustling and successful, with good landings of fish from the north all the way to Norway. Finally, I made four journeys to Wales and the North West of England. fields.headline: The ride of a lifetime
fields.standfirst: In the second of his articles on South America,  Hank Wangford saddles up to experience the breathtaking scenery of the Patagonian Alps.
fields.trailText: In the second of his articles on South America, Hank Wangford saddles up to experience the breathtaking scenery of the Patagonian Alps.
fields.body:
In the great divide of the Patagonian Alps, there is an area of biscuit-tin beauty - deep, dark lakes carved out by pleistocene glaciers in a dizzying mountain setting.

It is so disconcertingly alpine that it called to Austrians, Swiss and Germans who came and built San Carlos de Bariloche in their own image, full of fondue, smoked wild boar and wall-to-wall chocolate shops. There are photo-opportunities with torpid St Bernards with brandy casks, and buskers in lederhosen. It has Swiss chalets, Zuric gnomes and an overweening love of lacquered logs. There are telephone boxes, bus stops, rubbish bins and whole churches of lacquered logs. Bungalows, signposts, tea houses; even the police station is shiny and varnished.

Bariloche is a good town for food. Many restaurants offer cheap $6-$15 set meals, and you won't have to pay more than $10 for a good bottle of wine. I had a massive $6 five-star fillet steak served by a waiter with bandana and ballooning bombachas , gaucho pants, at La Vizcacha (Rolando 279). La Familia Weiss (Palacios 167) is one of the best middle-European restaurants with smoked game and fish, trout, wild boar and venison. A meal for two with wine costs $50-$60.

But, despite the fine food, Bariloche is a young, unlovely town thrown up for tourists. Outside is a different world.

Tucked away down the lakeside road are some tasteful traditional hotels. Ours was Hotel Tunquelen, 25km away at Llao Llao, down by the lake in ancient towering woods of southern beech, lenga and coihue, and massive sequoia-like alerces. Beyond are peaks such as the Cathedral and the Thunderer, a mountainous adventure wonderland with glorious walking, climbing, trekking, skiing and horse riding. Down the road towers the sheer rock face of Mount Lopez. A fine three-hour walk to the top gives views up the lakes towards Chile.

I came to meet Carol Jones, the grand-daughter of a half-Welsh half-Cherokee adventurer Jarred Jones who had come down from Texas in 1887 to make his fortune. He found no gold but worked hard and bought two estancias - ranches - one on the lake and one in the mountains. Carol has inherited his Cherokee cheekbones and his horsemanship. She is muy gaucha, a real horsewoman as they say here, little wonder then that she is responsible for opening the first riding stables round these parts.

Carol was waiting in her weather-beaten old cowboy hat and her battered Land Rover, and we drove for two hours with a trailer full of saddles, tack and supplies to Jarred's mountain estancia. The journey took us from the Latin equivalent of the lakeside Swiss Alps to the backcountry of Wyoming. The frontier was a row of pink pinnacles grasping at the sky, home to vultures and condors. Jarred's estancia, Las Mellizas, The Twins, is right up on the Great Divide. Two rivers that start up here go in opposite directions, one through Chile to the Pacific ocean and the other to the Atlantic.

Set in a valley below a craggy mountain, the estancia consists of a few wooden shacks, with an occasional animal skin stretched over the tin roof, an old log corral, some hitching posts and saddle rails and two little adobe casitas. Half a side of beef was hanging in a big wood and wire-mesh box.

A gaucho and his young family lived in one casita, looking after 450 head of cattle and 25 horses. It was autumn and talk was of the three-day drive down to the lakeside for the winter.

We had come up with Carol and Lucio, a taciturn young gaucho who picked out and saddled the horses, made and tended the campfires, roasted the asado, all with effortless ease and without a word. Simple things done well. Meat, salt and fire.

The riding was spectacular. We rode for two days across valleys with condors swooping over our heads, and along high mountain ridges way above the condors' nests looking down over the Patagonian wastelands.

The horses were criollo, the sturdy thick-necked Argentine breed, good natured and surefooted on these narrow trails. We sat on mountain saddles like the Chileans, a high-cantled wood, leather and metal frame, covered with leather and sheepskin, very comfortable, raised from the horse's back and good for the steep climbs and descents.

Camping out in the mountains, we fell asleep to the sound of the tucu tucus, small burrowing animals hammering away in the ground underneath us. Sitting by the campfire in the valley when the southern full moon slipped over the ridge, Mrs Wangford saw it upside down for the first time.

The landscape was spellbinding. No wonder Jarred came here. No wonder Butch Cassidy settled down the road in Cholila. It was the ride of a lifetime.

For something a little less strenuous, try the chairlift up Cerro Campanario for the best view of Nahuel Huapí lake and its glorious ring of Alpine mountains. Cathedral Mountain, full of pinnacles and notched ridges, offers Argentina's top rock climbing with several chairlifts and superb trekking and camping.

There is a cablecar up Mount Otto to an odd circu lar structure. Mrs Wangford thought it was some unidentified flying toilet. It isn't. You can paraglide down from the top, lakes and mountains around you.

We decided to paraglide on to an old lounging sofa in the revolving restaurant and watched an evening halo settle over the Thunderer's peak as the sun set over Chile and the magical panorama tiptoed past.

A boat trip out to Isla Hoemul is bizarre. There they proudly show you the derelict laboratories and reactor buildings of a lunatic nuclear project, the most elephantine of all white elephants. Ronaldo Richter, a paranoid Austrian scientist, had some unworkable plans for atomic energy and in the 1950s took Peron to the cleaners for $62m without producing a single spark of atomic energy. But he looked right, was crazy and spoke German, so they gave him all their money.

Other strange inhabitants of the Hoemul are the arrayanes, ghostly etiolated trees with peeling cinnamon bark that are stone cold to the touch, as cold as death.

They are a holy tree to the Araucanian indians who make their drink chicha from the seeds. The fishermen love it here too. The local brochure is dismissive of the folks over the hills: "Unlike Chile where it rains all year round and the salmons are of fish hatcheries, you will be amazed with our savage ingenuous trouts size." Hmm. Savage Ingenuous Trouts eh? Sounds like an Indie band.

The practicals

British Airways (0345 222111) flies to Buenos Aires from £445 return. Hank Wangford flew from Buenos Aires to Bariloche on a LAPA Discover Argentina Airpass, $339 for three return flights, $100 for each extra leg , details 020-7707 4576. He stayed at the Hotel Tunquelen (0944 48233); double rooms with a lakeside view $110 low season, $165 high season. Carol Jones (tel 054 2944-426508, fax: 054 2944-422996, e-mail: caroljones@infovia.com offers 2-10 day rides for $120 per day all in. For general tourist information, call the Argentine embassy in London: 020-7318 1300.

A boat trip out to Isla Hoemul is bizarre. There they proudly show you the derelict laboratories and reactor buildings of a lunatic nuclear project, the most elephantine of all white elephants. Ronaldo Richter, a paranoid Austrian scientist, had some unworkable plans for atomic energy and in the 1950s took Peron to the cleaners for $62m without producing a single spark of atomic energy. But he looked right, was crazy and spoke German, so they gave him all their money. Other strange inhabitants of the Hoemul are the arrayanes, ghostly etiolated trees with peeling cinnamon bark that are stone cold to the touch, as cold as death. They are a holy tree to the Araucanian indians who make their drink chicha from the seeds. The fishermen love it here too. The local brochure is dismissive of the folks over the hills: "Unlike Chile where it rains all year round and the salmons are of fish hatcheries, you will be amazed with our savage ingenuous trouts size." Hmm. Savage Ingenuous Trouts eh? Sounds like an Indie band. The practicals British Airways (0345 222111) flies to Buenos Aires from £445 return. Hank Wangford flew from Buenos Aires to Bariloche on a LAPA Discover Argentina Airpass, $339 for three return flights, $100 for each extra leg , details 020-7707 4576. He stayed at the Hotel Tunquelen (0944 48233); double rooms with a lakeside view $110 low season, $165 high season. Carol Jones (tel 054 2944-426508, fax: 054 2944-422996, e-mail: caroljones@infovia.com offers 2-10 day rides for $120 per day all in. fields.headline: Ask a fellow traveller
fields.standfirst: Helen Jacobs wanted to know where she could buy an electronic mosquito deterrent.
fields.trailText: Helen Jacobs wanted to know where she could buy an electronic mosquito deterrent.
fields.body:
They are made by The Edge Company, 17 Kit Street, Keene, NH 03431, US, (tel: 1 800 732 9976, www.edgeco.com). There are two types of device; one is about the size of a large wristwatch and costs $19.95; the other is like a medium size chest microphone and costs $5.95. Credit cards are OK. There is only one problem: Edge does not seem keen to send things abroad. I got mine by giving a friend's address in the States.
Michael Mann

The devices that Helen Jacobs wants are made by: Servicroma, C/Foc, 23, 08038 Barcelona, Spain (tel: 93 223 45 64, www.radarcan.com). I bought an SC-7 model for £5 in a hardware shop in Soria, Spain. It works very well and seems to run forever on a single AA battery. Some jokers in the UK are apparently trying to sell them for £20.
Aidan Rowe

Mary Russell wanted to buy a Dog Dazer

I used an ordinary rape alarm (much cheaper - about £5) against a pack of sheepdogs in the Pindos Mountains. Greek sheepdogs are notoriously ferocious, and these were racing towards us. The rape alarm stopped them dead in their tracks. They then dithered long enough for us to back away.
Liz Allen

This week's question

My husband comes from a large family (32 at the last count). We all like to holiday together but find it very difficult to get suitable self-catering accommodation in the UK. We would welcome any advice on self catering for large groups.
Lesley Sainsbury
