webTitle: Three-fifths of failing schools raise standards

fields.headline: Three-fifths of failing schools raise standards
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: A dramatic turnaround in standards within England's failing schools was revealed yesterday by the government's schools watchdog Ofsted, showing that up to 250,000 youngsters have benefited from huge improvements in the quality of teaching and leadership.
fields.body:
A dramatic turnaround in standards within England's failing schools was revealed yesterday by the government's schools watchdog Ofsted, showing that up to 250,000 youngsters have benefited from huge improvements in the quality of teaching and leadership.

The first detailed analysis of how 600 of the worst performing primary and secondary schools fared after emerging from "special measures" showed that after being identified as failing, the vast majority of schools had engineered a significant turnaround within two to four years.

Improvements were recorded in pupil achievement as well as in standards of teaching, leadership and management, and were found to be more marked in primary schools than in secondary schools.

Ministers claimed the new evidence showed that Labour's policies to raise standards in schools were working, and that it should silence those who have criticised the tough inspection regime overseen by the office for standards in education and originally introduced by the Tories.

The analysis was presented by senior Ofsted officials at a bilateral conference in Washington on turning around failing schools. The US government and regional school districts are particularly interested in the role of Ofsted in monitoring and inspecting schools, as America has no comparable system.

In 1993 Ofsted started its programme of inspecting and publishing a report on every school in England which receives state funding, with powers to put any school deemed to be failing or likely to fail into "special measures". This means the school has to produce an action plan for recovery and is subject to further monitoring by Ofsted.

In 1992-93 there were more than 1,000 schools put into special measures, from which around 600 have come out after achieving satisfactory improvements and being subjected to a reinspection by Ofsted. Of those that did not improve sufficiently, 132 have been closed and had pupils dispersed elsewhere, and 16 closed and reopened as "fresh start" schools.

The new research showed that on academic achievement alone, the primary schools had seen a massive improvement based on the results of key stage two national test results. At one London school, only 20% of 11-year-olds achieved the required standards in Eng lish, maths and science in 1997, a figure that leaped to 70%, 75% and 83% in each of the subjects in this year's tests.

Of 10 secondary schools closely tracked by Ofsted, the amount of satisfactory or better teaching had been less than two-thirds when the schools went into special measures, but went up to 100% after coming out. There were also reversals in the quality of school leadership at both primary and secondary level.

Mike Tomlinson, head of inspections at Ofsted, said yesterday: "This clearly shows that between 150,000 and 250,000 pupils are getting a far better deal from their education. The special measures policy is working, because it has enabled us to expose the weaknesses in schools and tackle them."

Elizabeth Passmore, head of the school improvement division at Ofsted, said that in some cases the former failing schools were so successful and popular that they were now oversubscribed. "This is happening to schools like the Ridings [in Yorkshire] which once would have been unthinkable."

But both admitted there was more work to be done in preventing the relatively high proportion - 12% - of schools deemed to have serious weaknesses from going into special measures.

webTitle: New query by teachers' union on performance pay

fields.headline: New query by teachers' union on performance pay
fields.trailText: The government has been warned that its system for introducing performance-related pay rises for classroom teachers could face legal challenges from staff who do not receive them.
fields.body:
The government has been warned that its system for introducing performance-related pay rises for classroom teachers could face legal challenges from staff who do not receive them.

The National Union of Teachers is demanding the right for staff to appeal to an independent body if their application for the £2,000 threshold payment is turned down. The union believes teachers could have a case if their application is supported by their headteacher but rejected by external assessors.

Doug McAvoy, the NUT general secretary, has told the schoolteachers review body that the external assessors system has "blatant unfairness".

But Nigel de Gruchy, general secretary of the National Union of Schoolmasters Union of Women Teachers, last night accused the NUT of again delaying the pay award.

In July the high court supported the NUT claim that David Blunkett, the education secretary, had broken the law by imposing new standards without proper consultation.

The government has been forced to bring its proposals before the review body, whose report on the threshold plan is expected shortly. First instalments were due last month, although the NUT argues that even without the court case the money would not have been delivered by then.
